title: Apples — a memorable story of forgetting
text:
The past 16 months linger in the mind watching mordant Greek puzzler Apples, a tale of society in the grip of a pandemic. Theirs is stranger than ours, however — an outbreak of amnesia drizzled over a grey-sky Athens. Not everyone is vulnerable, but for those who are, the wipe-clean is total. Take the allegory any way you want.

At first, director Christos Nikou simply focuses on cerebral slapstick. A traffic jam builds up after a motorist abandons his car, suddenly at a loss as to how to drive it. Another unfortunate reaches the last stop on a bus route. Shortly after getting on, he just forgot where he was going. This hapless figure — lean and doleful, played by Aris Servetalis — becomes our hero. He is taken to hospital, where no relatives claim him. It is possible, the doctors smile sadly, that they too have now forgotten he exists.

Film-making can be contagious as well. Nikou formerly worked as an assistant to Yorgos Lanthimos, the director whose 2018 awards magnet The Favourite followed a series of chilly, funny, deeply unrelaxed art house hits. Apples is sweeter but shares a lot with the film Lanthimos and Nikou made together, the gloriously spiky Dogtooth. As it was there, the tone is angular, the setting a present untouched by digital technology — cassette recorders and Polaroids feature heavily. The film proceeds in skits; the drollery fractionally wears thin. Then comes the entrance of Anna (Sofia Georgovassili) — a matching amnesiac and a beginning again both for Servetalis and Apples. The question of what we might be when we can't remember who we are is made fresh once more. The answer, not so weirdly, is altogether moving.

★★★★☆

On Curzon Home Cinema in the UK from May 7
